solution:
One word substitute is Shredding.
Slashing: vigorously incisive or effective.
Ripping: splendid; excellent.
Shredding: a piece cut or torn off, especially in a narrow strip. a bit; scrap.
Disposing: get rid of by throwing away or giving or selling to someone else.

qText: He is very careful and particular about everything he does.
solution:
One word substitute is Meticulous.
Precise: marked by exactness and accuracy of expression or detail.
Careless: not giving sufficient attention or thought to avoiding harm or errors.
Meticulous: showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
Conscientious: wishing to do one's work or duty well and thoroughly.

qText: Virus is a biological entity which lives on another organism.
solution:
One word substitute is Parasite.
Dependant: a person who relies on another, especially a family member, for financial support.
Parasite: an organism that lives in or on an organism of another species (its host) and benefits by deriving nutrients at the other's expense.
Symbiotic: involving interaction between two different organisms living in close physical association.
Plebiscite: the direct vote of all the members of an electorate on an important public question such as a change in the constitution.

qText: Submarines operate below the surface of the seas.
solution:
One word substitute is Subterranean.
Superfluous: unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
Surreptitious: kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of.
Perspicacious: having a ready insight into and understanding of things.
Subterranean: existing, occurring, or done under the earth's surface.

qText: The committee insisted on a total check on all social evils and he was the one who heralded the revolution.
solution:
One word substitute is Harbinger.
Harbinger: a person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another.
Apostate: a person who renounces a religious or political belief or principle.
Renegade: a person who deserts and betrays an organization, country, or set of principles.
Apostle: each of the twelve chief disciples of Jesus Christ.

qText: The complete eradication of poverty is an unreal and visionary ideal.
solution:
One word substitute is Chimerical.
Meditative: relating to or absorbed in meditation or considered thought.
Fantastic: extraordinarily good or attractive.
Chimerical: hoped for but illusory or impossible to achieve.
Contemplative: expressing or involving prolonged thought.

qText: The officer was not willing to take a definite stand on that point.
solution:
One word substitute is Evasive.
Vague: of uncertain, indefinite, or unclear character or meaning.
Evasive: tending to avoid commitment or self-revelation, especially by responding only indirectly.
Ambiguous: open to more than one interpretation; not having one obvious meaning.
Complex: consisting of many different and connected parts.

qText: Rajiv Gandhi was awarded 'Bharat Ratna' after his death.
solution:
One word substitute is Posthumous.
Ephemeral: lasting for a very short time.
Posthumous: occurring, awarded, or appearing after the death of the originator.
Extempore: spoken or done without preparation.
Maiden: an unmarried girl or young woman.

qText: Every person is not allowed to enter the place where public, government or historical records are kept.
solution:
One word substitute is Archives.
Scullery: a small kitchen or room at the back of a house used for washing dishes and other dirty household work.
Pantry: a small room or cupboard in which food, crockery, and cutlery are kept.
Archives: a collection of historical documents or records providing information about a place, institution, or group of people.
Coffer: a strongbox or small chest for holding valuables.

qText: The stableman at the inn was the only witness to the murder.
solution:
One word substitute is Ostler.
Butler: the chief manservant of a house.
Ostler: a man employed to look after the horses of people staying at an inn.
Imposter: a person who pretends to be someone else in order to deceive others, especially for fraudulent gain.
Jockey: a person who rides in horse races, especially as a profession.

qText: A soldier who fights for sake of money cannot be branded as courageous and patriotic.
solution:
One word substitute is Mercenary.
Sinecure: a position requiring little or no work but giving the holder status or financial benefit.
Honorary: conferred as an honour, without the usual requirements or functions.
Mercenary: primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics.
Equestrian: relating to horse riding.

qText: The discovery of the instrument with lenses for making very small objects appear larger widened our scope of knowledge.
solution:
One word substitute is Microscope.
Telescope: an optical instrument designed to make distant objects appear nearer, containing an arrangement of lenses, or of curved mirrors and lenses, by which rays of light are collected and focused and the resulting image magnified.
Binoculars: an optical instrument with a lens for each eye, used for viewing distant objects.
Microscope: an optical instrument used for viewing very small objects, such as mineral samples or animal or plant cells, typically magnified several hundred times.
Bioscope: a cinema or film.

qText: Tuberculosis is a disease which spreads by contact.
solution:
One word substitute is Contagious.
Infectious: (of a disease or disease-causing organism) liable to be transmitted to people, organisms, etc. through the environment.
Contiguous: sharing a common border; touching.
Fatal: causing death.
Contagious: (of a disease) spread from one person or organism to another, typically by direct contact.

qText: During the Sultanate rule in India, men were not allowed to enter the women's part of dwelling.
solution:
One word substitute is Harem.
Wardrobe: a large, tall cupboard or recess in which clothes may be hung or stored.
Pantry: a small room or cupboard in which food, crockery, and cutlery are kept.
Harem: (in former times) the separate part of a Muslim household reserved for wives, concubines, and female servants.
Anteroom: an antechamber, typically serving as a waiting room.

qText: The caretaker of a public building needs to a vigilant and an honest person.
solution:
One word substitute is Custodian.
Custodian: a person who has responsibility for taking care of or protecting something.
Curator: a manager or overseer.
Watchman: a man employed to look after an empty building, especially at night.
Dean: the head of a university faculty or department or of a medical school.

qText: The shelter for cow ought to be clean and well ventilated.
solution:
One word substitute is Byre.
Hutch: a box or cage, typically with a wire mesh front, for keeping rabbits or other small domesticated animals.
Byre: a cowshed.
Hangar: a large building with an extensive floor area, typically for housing aircraft.
Kennel: a small shelter for a dog.
Barracks: a large building or group of buildings used to house soldiers.

qText: He does unpaid work for the Red Cross.
solution:
One word substitute is Honorary.
Honorific: given as a mark of respect but having few or no duties.
Honest: free of deceit; truthful and sincere.
Honorary: (of an office or its holder) unpaid.
Honourable: bringing or deserving honour.

qText: The advertisement assured the public that the medicine would give back to the users, their youthful vigour and appearance.
solution:
One word substitute is Rejuvenate.
Rejuvenate: make (someone or something) look or feel better, younger, or more vital.
Restore: bring back or re-establish (a previous right, practice, or situation).
Replenish: fill (something) up again.
Render: provide or give (a service, help, etc.).

qText: A nation engaged in war cannot attain high levels of excellence in cultural fields.
solution:
One word substitute is Belligerent.
Bellicose: demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight.
Belligerent: engaged in a war or conflict, as recognized by international law.
Imperialist: relating to, supporting, or practising imperialism.
Courageous: not deterred by danger or pain; brave.

qText: Government by all cannot ensure order.
solution:
One word substitute is Pantisocracy.
Democracy: a system of government by the whole population or all the eligible members of a state, typically through elected representatives.
Bureaucracy: a system of government in which most of the important decisions are taken by state officials rather than by elected representatives.
Plutocracy: government by the wealthy.
Pantisocracy: a form of utopian social organization in which all are equal in social position and responsibility.

qText: We should always be grateful to one who has suffered for a great cause.
solution:
One word substitute is Martyr.
Fanatic: a person filled with excessive and single-minded zeal, especially for an extreme religious or political cause.
Martyr: a constant sufferer from (an ailment).
Devotee: a person who is very interested in and enthusiastic about someone or something.
Patriot: a person who vigorously supports their country and is prepared to defend it against enemies or detractors.

qText: Ravi impressed everyone with his persuasive and fluent speech.
solution:
One word substitute is Eloquence.
Discourse: written or spoken communication or debate.
Expression: the action of making known one's thoughts or feelings.
Eloquence: fluent or persuasive speaking or writing.
Lecture: an educational talk to an audience, especially one of students in a university.

qText: You are requested to send a list of goods sent, with their prices along with the parcel so that the payment can be done immediately.
solution:
One word substitute is Invoice.
Agenda: a list of items to be discussed at a formal meeting.
Invoice: a list of goods sent or services provided, with a statement of the sum due for these; a bill.
Catalogue: a complete list of items, typically one in alphabetical or other systematic order.
Inventory: a complete list of items such as property, goods in stock, or the contents of a building.

qText: A careful preservation and protection od wildlife is the need of the hour.
solution:
One word substitute is Conservation.
Embarkment: the process of loading a passenger ship or an airplane with passengers or military personnel, related to and overlapping with individual boarding on aircraft and ships.
Promotion: activity that supports or encourages a cause, venture, or aim.
Conservation: preservation, protection, or restoration of the natural environment and of wildlife.
Management: the process of dealing with or controlling things or people.

qText: The servant had not even left the place when a sudden rush of wind blew away the clothes which he had just tried.
solution:
One word substitute is Gust.
Breeze: a gentle wind.
Storm: a violent disturbance of the atmosphere with strong winds and usually rain, thunder, lightning, or snow.
Gale: a very strong wind.
Typhoon: a tropical storm in the region of the Indian or western Pacific oceans.
Gust: a sudden strong rush of wind.

qText: The education in primitive gurukuls comprised mainly of telling the stories of old time gods or heroes.
solution:
One word substitute is Legend.
Ode: a lyric poem, typically one in the form of an address to a particular subject, written in varied or irregular metre.
Epic: a long poem, typically one derived from ancient oral tradition, narrating the deeds and adventures of heroic or legendary figures or the past history of a nation.
Allegory: a story, poem, or picture that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning, typically a moral or political one.
Legend: a traditional story sometimes popularly regarded as historical but not authenticated.

qText: Sunil was buying tickets at the counter when suddenly he noticed a lady's purse lying on the floor.
solution:
One word substitute is Reticule.
Reticule: a woman's small handbag, typically having a drawstring and decorated with embroidery or beading.
Parasol: a light umbrella used to give shade from the sun.
Vestibule: an antechamber, hall, or lobby next to the outer door of a building.
Veil: a piece of fine material worn by women to protect or conceal the face.

qText: The most common local means of transport in British times was a two-wheeled cab for two to ride inside with driver mounted up behind.
solution:
One word substitute is Hansom.
Carriage: any of the separate sections of a train that carry passengers.
Wagon: a vehicle used for transporting goods or another specified purpose.
Locomotive: a powered railway vehicle used for pulling trains.
Hansom: a two-wheeled horse-drawn cab accommodating two inside, with the driver seated behind.

qText: Study of environment is a newly evolving branch of science.
solution:
One word substitute is Ecology.
Geography: the study of the physical features of the earth and its atmosphere, and of human activity as it affects and is affected by these, including the distribution of populations and resources and political and economic activities.
Ethnology: the study of the characteristics of different peoples and the differences and relationships between them.
Geology: the science which deals with the physical structure and substance of the earth, their history, and the processes which act on them.
Ecology: the branch of biology that deals with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings.

qText: A loud talk or speech is never impressive.
solution:
One word substitute is Harangue.
Magniloquence: use of high-flown language.
Harangue: a lengthy and aggressive speech.
Erudition: the quality of having or showing great knowledge or learning; scholarship.
Malevolence: the state or condition of being malevolent; hostility.

qText: It is custom of Christianity to sing morning prayer in the church regularly.
solution:
One word substitute is Matin.
Epilogue: a section or speech at the end of a book or play that serves as a comment on or a conclusion to what has happened.
Matin: a Christian service of morning prayer, especially in the Anglican Church.
Epitaph: a phrase or form of words written in memory of a person who has died, especially as an inscription on a tombstone.
Vesper: evening prayer; vespers.

qText: Both Buddha and Mahavira lived at the same time.
solution:
One word substitute is Contemporary.
Simultaneous: occurring, operating, or done at the same time.
Contemporary: living or occurring at the same time.
Coincident: occurring together in space or time.
Synchronised: cause to occur or operate at the same time or rate.

qText: I find that your views are not to my liking.
solution:
One word substitute is Irritating.
Abhorrent: inspiring disgust and loathing; repugnant.
Irritating: causing annoyance, impatience, or mild anger.
Painful: (of a part of the body) affected with pain.
Revolting: causing intense disgust; disgusting.

qText: The conclusions derived from experiments showed deviation from common rule.
solution:
One word substitute is Anomaly.
Heterogeneity: the quality or state of being diverse in character or content.
Anomaly: something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected.
Anonymity: the condition of being anonymous.
Strange: unusual or surprising; difficult to understand or explain.

qText: The man's nervousness depicted that it was the first speech delivered by him.
solution:
One word substitute is Maiden.
Matin: a Christian service of morning prayer, especially in the Anglican Church.
Peroration: the concluding part of a speech, typically intended to inspire enthusiasm in the audience.
Maiden: being or involving the first attempt or act of its kind.
Platitude: a remark or statement, especially one with a moral content, that has been used too often to be interesting or thoughtful.

qText: We are looking forward to a good winter this year.
solution:
One word substitute is Hoping.
Encouraging: giving someone support or confidence; supportive.
Getting: come to have (something); receive.
Hoping: want something to happen or be the case.
Visualising: form a mental image of; imagine.

qText: Rajesh was a hater of learning and knowledge.
solution:
One word substitute is Misologist.
Misogynist: a person who dislikes, despises, or is strongly prejudiced against women.
Misologist: the hatred of reasoning.
Misanthropist: a person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
Bibliophile: a person who collects or has a great love of books.

qText: No theorem can be proved without using the statements which are taken for granted.
solution:
One word substitute is Postulates.
Maxims: a short, pithy statement expressing a general truth or rule of conduct.
Tenets: a principle or belief, especially one of the main principles of a religion or philosophy.
Postulates: suggest or assume the existence, fact, or truth of (something) as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or belief.
Stipulation: a condition or requirement that is specified or demanded as part of an agreement.

qText: Not many people were impressed by a speech delivered without previous preparation.
solution:
One word substitute is Extempore.
Epilogue: a section or speech at the end of a book or play that serves as a comment on or a conclusion to what has happened.
Prologue: a separate introductory section of a literary, dramatic, or musical work.
Soliloquy: an act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when by oneself or regardless of any hearers, especially by a character in a play.
Extempore: spoken or done without preparation.

qText: This process is a long one as it involves too much official formality.
solution:
One word substitute is Red-tapism.
Diplomacy: the profession, activity, or skill of managing international relations, typically by a country's representatives abroad.
Bureaucracy: a system of government in which most of the important decisions are taken by state officials rather than by elected representatives.
Nepotism: the practice among those with power or influence of favouring relatives or friends, especially by giving them jobs.
Red-tapism: the practice of requiring excessive paperwork and tedious procedures before official action can be considered or completed.

qText: His father is a doctor who treats children and infants.
solution:
One word substitute is Paediatrician.
Dermatologist: a medical practitioner qualified to diagnose and treat skin disorders.
Gynaecologist: a physician or surgeon qualified to practise in gynaecology.
Podiatrist: a person who treats the feet and their ailments; a chiropodist.
Paediatrician: a medical practitioner specializing in children and their diseases.

qText: In the olden days, the king was considered all powerful.
solution:
One word substitute is Omnipotent.
Veteran: a person who has had long experience in a particular field.
Omnipotent: (of a deity) having unlimited power.
Omnivorous: (of an animal or person) feeding on a variety of food of both plant and animal origin.
Omniscient: knowing everything.

qText: Nowadays, we often come across cases of admission to institutions through counterfeit certificates and documents.
solution:
One word substitute is Forgery.
Stoicism: the endurance of pain or hardship without the display of feelings and without complaint.
Pugnacity: natural disposition to be aggressive or belligerent.
Epitaph: a phrase or form of words written in memory of a person who has died, especially as an inscription on a tombstone.
Forgery: a forged document, signature, banknote, or work of art.

qText: The automobile has tended to destroy without any trace the difference between rural and urban life.
solution:
One word substitute is Obliterate.
Cancel: decide or announce that (a planned event) will not take place.
Negate: make ineffective; nullify.
Obliterate: destroy utterly; wipe out.
Nullify: make legally null and void; invalidate.

qText: He is working in return for being taught the trade.
solution:
One word substitute is Apprentice.
Disciple: a personal follower of Christ during his life, especially one of the twelve Apostles.
Pupil: a person who is taught by another, especially a schoolchild or student in relation to a teacher.
Apprentice: a person who is learning a trade from a skilled employer, having agreed to work for a fixed period at low wages.
Sobriquet: a person's nickname.

qText: The bus has to go back and forth every six hours.
solution:
One word substitute is Commute.
Travel: make a journey, typically of some length.
Run: move at a speed faster than a walk, never having both or all the feet on the ground at the same time.
Shuttle: a form of transport that travels regularly between two places.
Commute: travel some distance between one's home and place of work on a regular basis.

qText: a man can be sentenced to death for killing another human being.
solution:
One word substitute is Homicide.
Fratricide: the killing of one's brother or sister.
Regicide: the action of killing a king.
Homicide: the killing of one person by another.
Genocide: the deliberate killing of a large group of people, especially those of a particular nation or ethnic group.

qText: Those who pass through this gate without permission will be prosecuted.
solution:
One word substitute is Trespassers.
Bypassers: one who or that which bypasses.
Culprits: a person who is responsible for a crime or other misdeed.
Absconders: a fugitive who runs away and hides to avoid arrest or prosecution.
Thoroughfares: a road or path forming a route between two places.
Trespassers: a person entering someone's land or property without permission.

qText: The fashion of bell-bottomed trousers has become out of date.
solution:
One word substitute is Obsolescent.
Preposterous: contrary to reason or common sense; utterly absurd or ridiculous.
Debilitating: (of a disease or condition) making someone very weak and infirm.
Obsolescent: becoming obsolete.
Obstreperous: noisy and difficult to control.

qText: Despite being in the career of singing for the last ten years, he has not been able to earn fame on account of his practice of borrowing ideas and words from others and using them as his own.
solution:
One word substitute is Plagiarism.
Adaptation: the action or process of adapting or being adapted.
Pantomime: a theatrical entertainment, mainly for children, which involves music, topical jokes, and slapstick comedy and is based on a fairy tale or nursery story, usually produced around Christmas.
Imitation: the action of using someone or something as a model.
Plagiarism: submitting someone's work as their own.
